appointment_subtitle: Schedule a confidential appointment with our support team
appt_disclaimer: We'll contact you within 24 hours to confirm your appointment. All sessions are confidential.
appt_notes_placeholder: Anything you'd like us to know before your session...
appt_text: Book a confidential counseling session with one of our trained support specialists. Sessions are available for various needs including therapy check-ins, consultations, and ongoing support.
article_anxiety_li10: Excessive worry that's hard to control
article_anxiety_li11: Feeling restless, keyed up, or on edge
article_anxiety_li12: Difficulty concentrating or mind going blank
article_anxiety_li14: Fear of losing control or "going crazy"
article_anxiety_li15: Feeling detached from yourself or surroundings
article_anxiety_li17: Antidepressants (SSRIs and SNRIs) are commonly prescribed
article_anxiety_li2: Shortness of breath or feeling of choking
article_anxiety_li20: Exercise regularly: Physical activity is a natural anxiety reliever. Aim for at least 30 minutes most days.
article_anxiety_li21: Practice relaxation techniques: Deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, and mindfulness meditation can calm your mind.
article_anxiety_li22: Get enough sleep: Poor sleep can worsen anxiety. Maintain a consistent sleep schedule.
article_anxiety_li23: Limit caffeine and alcohol: Both can trigger or worsen anxiety symptoms.
article_anxiety_li24: Connect with others: Social support is crucial. Talk to friends, family, or join a support group.
article_anxiety_li25: Challenge negative thoughts: Learn to identify and question anxious thoughts.
article_anxiety_li26: Your anxiety is interfering with work, relationships, or daily activities
article_anxiety_li27: You're avoiding situations due to fear
article_anxiety_li28: Your anxiety feels impossible to control
article_anxiety_li29: You're experiencing depression along with anxiety
article_anxiety_li30: You're using alcohol or drugs to cope
article_anxiety_li31: You have thoughts of self-harm or suicide
article_anxiety_p1: Anxiety is a normal human emotion that everyone experiences from time to time. It's the feeling of worry, nervousness, or unease about something with an uncertain outcome. In fact, some anxiety can be helpfulâ€”it can alert us to dangers and help us prepare for important events.
article_anxiety_p10: Anxiety disorders don't have a single cause. Instead, they result from a combination of factors:
article_anxiety_p11: Anxiety disorders tend to run in families. If you have a close relative with an anxiety disorder, you may be more likely to develop one yourself. However, having a genetic predisposition doesn't mean you will definitely develop anxiety.
article_anxiety_p12: Research suggests that anxiety disorders may be linked to faulty circuits in the brain that regulate fear and emotions. Neurotransmitters like serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine play important roles in mood regulation.
article_anxiety_p13: Traumatic events, chronic stress, childhood adversity, and significant life changes can trigger anxiety disorders. This includes experiences like abuse, loss of a loved one, divorce, job loss, or major health problems.
article_anxiety_p14: Certain personality traits, such as being shy, having low self-esteem, or being a perfectionist, may make some people more prone to anxiety disorders.
article_anxiety_p15: Anxiety disorders are highly treatable. The main treatments include psychotherapy, medication, or a combination of both.
article_anxiety_p16: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) is the most effective form of psychotherapy for anxiety disorders. CBT teaches you different ways of thinking, behaving, and reacting to anxiety-producing situations. It can also help you learn and practice social skills, which is vital for treating social anxiety disorder.
article_anxiety_p17: Exposure therapy is a component of CBT that focuses on confronting the fears underlying an anxiety disorder. It helps you engage with activities or situations you may have been avoiding.
article_anxiety_p18: Several types of medications can help relieve symptoms of anxiety disorders:
article_anxiety_p19: Always work with your healthcare provider to find the right medication and dosage for your specific needs.
article_anxiety_p2: However, anxiety becomes a disorder when it's excessive, difficult to control, and interferes with daily life. Anxiety disorders are the most common mental health conditions, affecting approximately 40 million adults in the United States alone.
article_anxiety_p20: In addition to professional treatment, these strategies can help manage anxiety:
article_anxiety_p21: Consider reaching out to a mental health professional if:
article_anxiety_p22: Remember, seeking help is a sign of strength, not weakness. Anxiety disorders are real, serious, and treatable. With proper treatment, many people with anxiety disorders lead full, productive lives.
article_anxiety_p3: Unlike the relatively mild, brief anxiety caused by a stressful event, anxiety disorders last at least 6 months and can get worse if not treated. The good news is that anxiety disorders are highly treatable, yet only about one-third of those suffering receive treatment.
article_anxiety_p4: People with GAD experience persistent and excessive worry about various aspects of daily life, including work, health, family, money, or everyday matters. The worry is often out of proportion to the actual likelihood or impact of the anticipated events. Physical symptoms may include restlessness, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, muscle tension, and sleep problems.
article_anxiety_p5: Panic disorder involves recurrent, unexpected panic attacksâ€”sudden periods of intense fear that come on quickly and reach their peak within minutes. During a panic attack, people may experience heart palpitations, sweating, trembling, shortness of breath, chest pain, nausea, dizziness, and fear of losing control or dying. Many people with panic disorder worry about when the next attack will happen and actively try to prevent future attacks.
article_anxiety_p6: Also known as social phobia, this involves intense fear of social or performance situations where one might be judged, embarrassed, or humiliated. People with social anxiety may avoid social situations or endure them with significant distress. This can affect work, school, and relationships.
article_anxiety_p7: A specific phobia is an intense, irrational fear of a specific object, situation, or activity that poses little to no actual danger. Common phobias include fear of heights, flying, spiders, blood, or enclosed spaces. People with phobias often go to great lengths to avoid what they fear.
article_anxiety_p8: While often thought of as a childhood condition, separation anxiety can occur in adults too. It involves excessive fear or anxiety about separation from attachment figures, worry about harm coming to loved ones, and reluctance to leave home or be alone.
article_anxiety_p9: Anxiety manifests in both physical and psychological ways. Recognizing these symptoms is the first step toward getting help.
article_anxiety_subtitle: A comprehensive guide to understanding what anxiety disorders are, how they manifest, and the evidence-based treatments available.
article_anxiety_title: Understanding Anxiety Disorders: Symptoms, Types, and Treatment
article_depression_li1: Persistent sad, anxious, or empty mood that lasts most of the day, nearly every day
article_depression_li10: Slowed movements or speech that others may notice
article_depression_li13: Thoughts of death or suicide - this is a serious symptom that requires immediate attention
article_depression_li14: Brain chemistry: Imbalances in neurotransmitters like serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine may contribute to depression
article_depression_li15: Genetics: Depression can run in families. Having a parent or sibling with depression increases your risk
article_depression_li16: Hormonal changes: Fluctuations in hormones can trigger depression, such as during pregnancy, postpartum, menopause, or thyroid problems
article_depression_li17: Trauma and abuse: Past physical, emotional, or sexual abuse can increase vulnerability to depression
article_depression_li18: Personality traits: People with low self-esteem, who are easily overwhelmed by stress, or who are generally pessimistic may be more prone to depression
article_depression_li19: Negative thinking patterns: Habitual negative thoughts can reinforce depressive feelings
article_depression_li2: Feelings of hopelessness or pessimism about the future
article_depression_li20: Major life changes: Job loss, divorce, death of a loved one, or other significant changes can trigger depression
article_depression_li21: Chronic stress: Ongoing stress from work, relationships, or financial problems can lead to depression
article_depression_li22: Social isolation: Lack of social support and meaningful connections increases depression risk
article_depression_li23: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): Helps identify and change negative thought patterns and behaviors
article_depression_li24: Interpersonal Therapy (IPT): Focuses on improving relationships and communication skills
article_depression_li25: Psychodynamic Therapy: Explores how past experiences influence current feelings and behaviors
article_depression_li26: SSRIs (Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors): Often the first-line treatment, including medications like fluoxetine and sertraline
article_depression_li27: SNRIs (Serotonin-Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitors): Another common option for depression
article_depression_li28: Other medications: Your doctor may recommend different options based on your specific situation
article_depression_li29: Brain stimulation therapies: Such as electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) or transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) for treatment-resistant depression
article_depression_li3: Feelings of guilt, worthlessness, or helplessness that seem excessive or inappropriate
article_depression_li30: Light therapy: Particularly effective for seasonal affective disorder
article_depression_li31: Exercise: Regular physical activity has been shown to reduce depression symptoms
article_depression_li32: Regular exercise: Aim for at least 30 minutes of physical activity most days. Even a short walk can help
article_depression_li33: Healthy eating: A balanced diet supports both physical and mental health
article_depression_li34: Quality sleep: Maintain a consistent sleep schedule and practice good sleep hygiene
article_depression_li35: Limit alcohol: Alcohol is a depressant and can worsen symptoms
article_depression_li36: Stay connected: Reach out to friends and family, even when you don't feel like it
article_depression_li37: Join a support group: Connecting with others who understand can be very helpful
article_depression_li38: Volunteer: Helping others can improve your mood and sense of purpose
article_depression_li39: Set realistic goals: Break tasks into smaller steps and celebrate small achievements
article_depression_li4: Loss of interest or pleasure in hobbies and activities you used to enjoy
article_depression_li40: Challenge negative thoughts: Question whether your negative thoughts are accurate
article_depression_li41: Practice mindfulness: Mindfulness and meditation can help reduce depressive symptoms
article_depression_li42: Do things you enjoy: Even if you don't feel like it, engaging in activities can improve your mood
article_depression_li43: Listen without judgment: Let them know you're there for them
article_depression_li44: Encourage professional help: Gently suggest they speak with a doctor or therapist
article_depression_li45: Offer practical support: Help with daily tasks like cooking, cleaning, or running errands
article_depression_li46: Be patient: Recovery takes time, and there may be setbacks
article_depression_li47: Take care of yourself: Supporting someone with depression can be emotionally draining
article_depression_li48: Don't minimize their feelings or tell them to "snap out of it"
article_depression_li49: Don't compare their situation to others or say "other people have it worse"
article_depression_li5: Irritability and frustration, even over small matters
article_depression_li50: Don't give unsolicited advice about what they should do
article_depression_li6: Changes in appetite - weight loss or gain unrelated to dieting
article_depression_li7: Sleep disturbances - insomnia or sleeping too much
article_depression_li8: Loss of energy or increased fatigue, even with adequate sleep
article_depression_li9: Physical aches and pains that don't have a clear cause
article_depression_p1: Depression, also known as major depressive disorder or clinical depression, is a common and serious mental health condition. It negatively affects how you feel, the way you think, and how you act. Depression causes feelings of sadness and a loss of interest in activities you once enjoyed.
article_depression_p10: The depressive phase of bipolar disorder, which also includes periods of mania or hypomania. This type requires different treatment approaches than unipolar depression.
article_depression_p11: Depression doesn't have a single cause. It typically results from a combination of factors:
article_depression_p12: Depression is one of the most treatable mental health conditions. Between 80 to 90 percent of people with depression eventually respond well to treatment.
article_depression_p13: Also known as talk therapy, psychotherapy helps people with depression understand and work through their feelings. Common approaches include:
article_depression_p14: Antidepressant medications can help correct chemical imbalances in the brain. Common types include:
article_depression_p15: It's important to work closely with a healthcare provider when taking medication, as finding the right medication and dosage can take time.
article_depression_p16: While professional treatment is often necessary, self-care strategies can support your recovery:
article_depression_p17: If someone you care about is experiencing depression, here's how you can help:
article_depression_p18: If someone expresses thoughts of suicide or self-harm, take it seriously. Stay with them, remove any means of self-harm if possible, and call emergency services or a crisis hotline immediately. In the US, you can call or text 988 for the Suicide and Crisis Lifeline.
article_depression_p2: It's important to understand that depression is different from normal sadness or grief. While everyone feels sad sometimes, depression is more persistent and can significantly interfere with daily life. Depression is not a weakness or a character flawâ€”it's a medical condition that can be treated.
article_depression_p3: Depression affects approximately 280 million people worldwide, making it one of the most common mental health conditions. It can occur at any age but often begins in adulthood. Women are more likely to experience depression than men, though men may be less likely to seek help.
article_depression_p4: Depression symptoms can vary from mild to severe. To be diagnosed with depression, symptoms must be present for at least two weeks and represent a change from your previous level of functioning.
article_depression_p5: Depression isn't a one-size-fits-all condition. There are several types, each with unique characteristics:
article_depression_p6: The most common form of depression, characterized by persistent feelings of sadness, hopelessness, and loss of interest. Symptoms must be present for at least two weeks and significantly impact daily functioning.
article_depression_p7: A chronic form of depression where symptoms last for at least two years. While symptoms may be less severe than major depression, they are long-lasting and can significantly affect quality of life.
article_depression_p8: Depression that follows a seasonal pattern, typically beginning in fall or winter when there's less natural sunlight. Symptoms usually improve in spring and summer. Light therapy is often effective for this type.
article_depression_p9: Depression that occurs after childbirth, affecting both mothers and fathers. It's more severe and longer-lasting than the "baby blues" and requires professional treatment.
article_depression_subtitle: A comprehensive guide to understanding what depression is, how it affects people, and the evidence-based treatments that can help.
article_depression_title: Understanding Depression: Symptoms, Causes, and Treatment
article_disclaimer: This content is for informational purposes only and is not a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment.
article_sleep_h2_2: How Much Sleep Do You Need?
article_sleep_li10: Keep it cool: The ideal bedroom temperature for sleep is around 65-68Â°F (18-20Â°C). A slightly cool room helps your body's natural temperature drop that occurs during sleep.
article_sleep_li11: Make it dark: Use blackout curtains or an eye mask to block light. Even small amounts of light can interfere with your circadian rhythm.
article_sleep_li12: Reduce noise: Use earplugs, a white noise machine, or a fan to mask disruptive sounds.
article_sleep_li13: Invest in comfort: A supportive mattress and comfortable pillows can make a significant difference. Replace your mattress every 7-10 years.
article_sleep_li14: Remove electronics: Keep TVs, computers, and smartphones out of the bedroom. The blue light they emit can suppress melatonin production.
article_sleep_li15: Set a 'wind-down' alarm: One hour before bed, start preparing for sleep.
article_sleep_li16: Turn off screens: Stop using phones, tablets, and computers at least 30 minutes before bed.
article_sleep_li17: Read a book: Reading (physical books, not e-readers with backlight) can help you relax.
article_sleep_li18: Take a warm bath or shower: The rise and fall in body temperature can promote drowsiness.
article_sleep_li19: Practice relaxation: Try deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, or gentle stretching.
article_sleep_li20: Write in a journal: Getting thoughts out of your head and onto paper can reduce bedtime worry.
article_sleep_li21: Listen to calming music: Soft, slow music can help you relax and prepare for sleep.
article_sleep_li22: You consistently have trouble falling or staying asleep
article_sleep_li23: You snore loudly or gasp for air during sleep
article_sleep_li24: You feel excessively tired during the day despite adequate sleep time
article_sleep_li25: You have restless legs or uncomfortable sensations at night
article_sleep_li26: Your sleep problems are affecting your daily life, work, or relationships
article_sleep_li27: You've tried sleep hygiene improvements for several weeks without success
article_sleep_p1: Sleep is not a luxuryâ€”it's a fundamental biological need. During sleep, your body repairs tissues, consolidates memories, and releases hormones that regulate growth and appetite. Quality sleep is essential for physical health, mental well-being, and cognitive function.
article_sleep_p10: While short naps can be beneficial, long or irregular napping during the day can negatively affect your nighttime sleep. If you choose to nap, limit it to 20-30 minutes in the early afternoon.
article_sleep_p11: Your bedroom environment plays a crucial role in sleep quality:
article_sleep_p12: A consistent bedtime routine signals to your body that it's time to wind down. Try these practices:
article_sleep_p13: If you can't fall asleep within 20 minutes, get out of bed and do something relaxing in dim light. Return to bed when you feel sleepy. This helps your brain associate your bed with sleep, not frustration.
article_sleep_p14: Brief awakenings during the night are normal. If you can't get back to sleep within 20 minutes, try the same techniqueâ€”get up, do something calming, and return when sleepy.
article_sleep_p15: Keep a notepad by your bed to write down worries or to-do items. This 'brain dump' can help clear your mind. You might also try mindfulness meditation to quiet racing thoughts.
article_sleep_p16: If you consistently wake up too early, try adjusting your bedtime or making sure your room stays dark in the morning hours. Exposure to bright light early in the evening can also help shift your sleep schedule.
article_sleep_p18: Sleep disorders like insomnia, sleep apnea, and restless legs syndrome are treatable. A doctor can help diagnose any underlying issues and recommend appropriate treatment.
article_sleep_p2: Chronic sleep deprivation is linked to serious health problems including obesity, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and weakened immune function. It also affects your mood, concentration, and decision-making abilities.
article_sleep_p3: The good news is that with proper sleep hygiene and habits, most people can significantly improve their sleep quality. Small changes can make a big difference.
article_sleep_p4: Sleep needs vary by age, but here are general guidelines from the National Sleep Foundation:
article_sleep_p5: Remember, these are guidelines. Some people naturally need more or less sleep. Pay attention to how you feelâ€”if you're consistently tired during the day, you may need more sleep.
article_sleep_p6: Sleep hygiene refers to habits and practices that promote quality sleep. Here are the fundamentals:
article_sleep_p7: Go to bed and wake up at the same time every day, even on weekends. This helps regulate your body's internal clock (circadian rhythm) and can help you fall asleep and wake up more easily.
article_sleep_p8: Caffeine can stay in your system for 6-8 hours, so avoid coffee, tea, and energy drinks in the afternoon and evening. While alcohol may help you fall asleep initially, it disrupts sleep quality later in the night.
article_sleep_p9: Regular physical activity can help you fall asleep faster and enjoy deeper sleep. However, try to finish exercising at least 3 hours before bedtime, as exercise can be stimulating.
article_sleep_subtitle: Science-backed strategies to improve your sleep quality and wake up feeling refreshed and energized.
article_sleep_title: Better Sleep: Your Complete Guide to Restful Nights
article_sleep_toc_2: How Much Sleep Do You Need?
article_stress_h2_4: Warning Signs of Too Much Stress
article_stress_li23: Having trouble sleeping or sleeping too much
article_stress_li24: Relying on alcohol, drugs, or food to cope
article_stress_li25: Physical symptoms without a clear medical cause
article_stress_li26: Withdrawing from friends and activities you enjoy
article_stress_li27: Exercise regularly: Physical activity produces endorphinsâ€”chemicals in the brain that act as natural painkillers and mood elevators. Aim for at least 30 minutes of moderate exercise most days.
article_stress_li28: Eat a balanced diet: A healthy diet can help counter the impact of stress by boosting your immune system and lowering blood pressure. Avoid excessive caffeine and sugar.
article_stress_li29: Get enough sleep: Stress often causes sleep problems, but lack of sleep also increases stress. Aim for 7-9 hours per night and maintain a consistent sleep schedule.
article_stress_li30: Limit alcohol and avoid drugs: These may seem to reduce stress temporarily but actually add to it in the long run.
article_stress_li31: Make time for hobbies: Engaging in activities you enjoy can be a great stress reliever. Whether it's reading, gardening, music, or artâ€”find what works for you.
article_stress_li32: Practice good time management: Plan ahead, prioritize tasks, and break projects into smaller steps. This can help reduce the stress of feeling overwhelmed.
article_stress_li33: Your stress symptoms persist despite self-help efforts
article_stress_li34: Stress is affecting your ability to work or maintain relationships
article_stress_li35: You're using unhealthy coping mechanisms (alcohol, drugs, overeating)
article_stress_li36: You're experiencing symptoms of anxiety or depression
article_stress_li37: You have physical symptoms that concern you
article_stress_li38: You feel hopeless or have thoughts of self-harm
article_stress_li5: Weakened immune system (getting sick more often)
article_stress_p1: Stress is your body's natural response to any demand or challenge. When you face a stressful situation, your body releases hormones like cortisol and adrenaline that prepare you to take action. This is often called the "fight or flight" response.
article_stress_p10: Deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, meditation, and yoga can activate your body's relaxation responseâ€”the opposite of the stress response. Even just 10-15 minutes a day can make a significant difference.
article_stress_p11: Social support is crucial for managing stress. Talk to friends, family, or a support group about what you're experiencing. Sometimes just sharing your feelings can provide relief.
article_stress_p12: When you're stressed, it's tempting to work harder to "power through." But taking regular breaks actually makes you more productive and helps prevent burnout. Step away from your work, take a walk, or do something enjoyable.
article_stress_p13: Learn to say no to requests that would create excessive stress in your life. It's okay to decline new responsibilities when you're already overwhelmed.
article_stress_p14: Rather than avoiding stressful situations, try to address them directly. Break large problems into smaller, manageable steps. Focus on what you can control and let go of what you can't.
article_stress_p15: Consider talking to a healthcare provider or mental health professional if:
article_stress_p16: A professional can help you identify sources of stress, develop effective coping strategies, and determine if you might benefit from therapy or medication.
article_stress_p2: In small doses, stress can be beneficial. It can help you stay focused, energetic, and alert. In emergency situations, stress can save your lifeâ€”giving you extra strength to defend yourself, for example, or spurring you to slam on the brakes to avoid an accident.
article_stress_p3: However, when stress becomes chronic or overwhelming, it can take a serious toll on your physical and mental health. Understanding how stress works and learning to manage it effectively is essential for your overall well-being.
article_stress_p4: This is the most common form of stress. It comes from demands and pressures of the recent past and anticipated demands and pressures of the near future. Acute stress is thrilling and exciting in small doses, but too much is exhausting. Examples include a job interview, a first date, or a deadline at work.
article_stress_p5: When acute stress happens frequently, it becomes episodic acute stress. People who suffer from this type of stress are often short-tempered, irritable, and anxious. They may describe themselves as having "a lot of nervous energy" or always being in a hurry.
article_stress_p6: This is the grinding stress that wears people away day after day, year after year. It destroys bodies, minds, and lives. Chronic stress comes from ongoing situations like an unhappy marriage, a toxic work environment, poverty, or chronic illness. The worst aspect of chronic stress is that people get used to it and may not even notice it anymore.
article_stress_p7: Chronic stress affects nearly every system in your body:
article_stress_p8: It's important to recognize when stress is becoming unmanageable. Watch for these warning signs:
article_stress_p9: Everyone copes with stress differently, but these evidence-based strategies can help:
article_stress_subtitle: A practical guide to understanding what stress is, how it affects you, and evidence-based strategies for managing it effectively.
article_stress_title: Managing Stress: Understanding and Coping Strategies
article_teen_toc_4: If You are a Teen Struggling
crisis_subtitle: If you or someone you know is in crisis, help is available right now.
crisis_text_text: Text HOME to 741741 for free, 24/7 crisis counseling.
download_failed: Failed to download audio. Please try again.
download_premium_only: Audio download is only available with premium voice.
faq_a1: Yes, the 988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline is completely free and available 24/7. You can call or text 988 from anywhere in the United States. The service is confidential and staffed by trained crisis counselors.
faq_a10: Focus on your breathing - try the 4-7-8 technique (breathe in for 4 seconds, hold for 7, exhale for 8). Ground yourself by naming 5 things you can see, 4 you can touch, 3 you can hear, 2 you can smell, and 1 you can taste. Remind yourself that panic attacks are temporary and not dangerous. If panic attacks are recurring, consider speaking with a mental health professional.
faq_a2: When you call a crisis line, you'll be connected with a trained counselor who will listen without judgment. They'll help you work through what you're feeling, provide support, and help you create a plan to stay safe. You don't need to be suicidal to call - any mental health crisis is valid.
faq_a3: Consider seeking professional help if your feelings are affecting your daily life, relationships, work, or school. Signs include persistent sadness, anxiety, changes in sleep or appetite, difficulty concentrating, or thoughts of self-harm. Remember: seeking help is a sign of strength, not weakness.
faq_a4: Yes, all counseling sessions are confidential. Mental health professionals are bound by strict privacy laws and ethical guidelines. The only exceptions are if there's an immediate risk of harm to yourself or others, or in cases involving abuse of minors or vulnerable adults.
faq_a5: There are many low-cost or free mental health options available. Community mental health centers often offer sliding-scale fees based on income. Many therapists offer reduced rates, and some nonprofits provide free counseling. Crisis lines like 988 are always free, and support groups can be a valuable no-cost resource.
faq_a6: Listen without judgment and let them know you care. Avoid trying to "fix" their problems - sometimes just being present is enough. Encourage them to seek professional help, and offer to help them find resources or accompany them to an appointment. Take any mention of self-harm seriously and don't be afraid to involve a trusted adult or crisis line if needed.
faq_a7: Therapists and counselors provide talk therapy and may have various credentials (LCSW, LPC, MFT). Psychologists have doctoral degrees and can provide therapy and psychological testing. Psychiatrists are medical doctors who can prescribe medication. Many people work with a combination - for example, a therapist for regular sessions and a psychiatrist for medication management.
faq_a8: Absolutely! It's very common to feel anxious about opening up to a stranger. A good therapist will understand this and help you feel comfortable at your own pace. Remember, you're in control of what you share and when. If after a few sessions you don't feel a connection, it's okay to try a different therapist - finding the right fit is important.
faq_a9: It varies greatly depending on your goals and situation. Some people benefit from short-term therapy (8-12 sessions) for specific issues like anxiety or stress management. Others may continue longer for deeper work or ongoing support. Your therapist will work with you to set goals and regularly assess your progress.
faq_intro_text: At MindBalance, we believe in being open and supportive. We know you may have questions about mental health, finding help, and how therapy works. Here are some of the most common questions we receive. If you don't find the answer you're looking for, feel free to reach out.
faq_q10: What should I do if I'm having a panic attack?
faq_q2: What happens when I call a crisis line?
faq_q3: How do I know if I need professional help?
faq_q5: What if I can't afford therapy?
faq_q6: How can I help a friend who's struggling?
faq_q7: What's the difference between a therapist, psychologist, and psychiatrist?
faq_q8: Is it normal to feel nervous about starting therapy?
faq_q9: How long does therapy usually take?
footer_about: MindBalance is a student-built mental health education and support hub. Our goal is to provide clear, reliable information and guide visitors toward safe resources.
footer_action_desc: Support mental health education and community access to resources.
hero_subtitle: Find support, resources, and guidance for your mental health journey. You're not alone.
highlight_select_article: Please select text within the article content.
highlight_select_first: Select some text first to highlight it.

hl_boystown_text: Help for teens and parents with any issue - abuse, anger, depression, school, and more.
hl_nami_text: Information, referrals, and support for mental health conditions.
hl_samhsa_text: Treatment referral service for mental health and substance abuse disorders.
hl_teenline_text: Teens helping teens with personal problems and difficult decisions.
hl_trevor_text: Crisis intervention and suicide prevention for LGBTQ+ young people.
hl_veterans_text: Free, confidential support for Veterans and their loved ones.
home_impact_communities_desc: Helping communities build awareness and make support more accessible for everyone.
home_impact_confidence_desc: Building confidence through clear information, real tools, and simple next steps.
home_impact_conversations_desc: Reducing stigma by making mental health easier to talk aboutâ€”without shame.
home_impact_educators_desc: Providing educators tools to recognize mental health needs and respond with care.
home_impact_families_desc: Supporting families with guidance to build healthier conversations and habits at home.
home_impact_reach_desc: People reached through MindBalance tools, education, and support resources.
home_impact_safespace_desc: Creating a place where people feel supported, respected, and understood.
home_impact_students_desc: Helping students manage stress, emotions, and mental wellness in school and beyond.
home_impact_support_desc: Connecting people to trusted resources so they can find help when they need it most.
home_welcome_desc: At MindBalance, we help people take care of their mental health. Our goal is to provide support, resources, and a safe space for everyone. We want to make mental health easier to understand and reduce the stigma around it.
intl_support_text: Find crisis lines and resources for your country.
quicklinks_subtitle: Choose a category to find the support you need
resource_anxiety_text: Learn about symptoms, causes, and management strategies for anxiety disorders.
resource_depression_text: Information about depression, treatment options, and recovery pathways.
resource_mindfulness_text: Guided exercises and tips for incorporating mindfulness into your routine.
resource_stress_text: Techniques and strategies for managing stress in daily life.
resourcelib_lead1: The MindBalance Resource Library is a searchable collection of educational information about mental health conditions. Explore topics to learn common symptoms, warning signs, and key facts in a clear, respectful way.
resourcelib_lead2: This page is informational and separate from Support Resources. If you need help right now, please use the Support page.
resourcelib_search_placeholder: Search for resources by title, description, tag, category...
resourcelib_support_note: If you or someone you know is in immediate danger, call 911. If you need urgent help, go to our Support page for 24/7 options.
resources_subtitle: Learn about common mental health topics
search_placeholder: Search for resources, topics, or support options...
selfhelp_breathing_step1: Breathe in quietly through your nose for 4 seconds
selfhelp_breathing_step3: Exhale completely through your mouth for 8 seconds
selfhelp_breathing_text: A simple 4-7-8 breathing technique to help calm your nervous system.
selfhelp_grounding_text: A grounding technique to help when feeling overwhelmed or anxious.
selfhelp_journal_prompt1: What am I grateful for today?
selfhelp_journal_prompt2: What emotions am I feeling right now?
selfhelp_journal_prompt3: What would I tell a friend in my situation?
selfhelp_journal_prompt4: What is one small step I can take today?
selfhelp_journal_text: Writing can help process emotions and gain clarity.
selfhelp_subtitle: Exercises you can do right now
sidebar_guest_desc: Read posts as a guest. Sign in to create posts, comment, and join discussions.
slide1_desc: Learn the symptoms, causes, and treatment options for common mental health disorders, including anxiety and depression. MindBalance provides clear information, trusted resources, and guidance to help individuals understand their mental health and take the next step toward support.
slide2_desc: Find trusted local and national helplines, text lines, and emergency resources. If you or someone you know needs help right now, this page makes it simple to reach support quickly.
slide3_desc: Use our appointment scheduler to request online counseling. Choose a time that works for you and get connected to support in a private, respectful way.
slide4_desc: Explore supportive conversations and real stories from people who have faced mental health challenges. Learn what helped them and share encouragement with others.
testimonial_1: MindBalance helped me understand my anxiety and build a routine that actually works. The tools are simple, but they made a big difference.
testimonial_10: I appreciate how the site explains symptoms and when to seek help. It's informative without being scary.
testimonial_11: MindBalance helped me identify burnout and build healthier boundaries. The suggestions felt realistic, not preachy.
testimonial_12: The site gave me a clear list of options for support and what to expect. It made reaching out feel less intimidating.
testimonial_2: The resource library made it easier to learn what my teen was experiencing. It gave us a better way to talk without judgment.
testimonial_3: I used the coping skills section during a really hard week. It didn't "fix everything," but it helped me feel grounded again.
testimonial_4: The self-check tools and education pages helped me recognize depression symptoms early and get support sooner.
testimonial_5: I learned how to support a friend dealing with panic attacks. MindBalance made the steps clear and respectful.
testimonial_6: The "what it is / what it isn't" explanations helped me understand OCD better. It stopped me from feeling alone.
testimonial_7: The library and guidance pages gave me a starting point for PTSD resources. It's organized and easy to navigate.
testimonial_8: The coping strategies are practical. I used them for social anxiety before presentations, and it helped me stay calm.
testimonial_9: The page layout is calming and easy to read. I found helpful info on ADHD without getting overwhelmed.
tts_keyboard_hint: Keyboard: Space to play/pause, Esc to stop, Ctrl+Arrow to skip
tts_keyboard_hint_enhanced: Keyboard: Space play/pause, Esc stop, Ctrl+Arrow skip, M mute, Arrow up/down volume
tts_not_supported: Text-to-speech is not supported in your browser.
tts_premium_unavailable: Premium voice is not available. Using browser voice.
profile_goals_cta: Set a wellness goal to get started
